reviewText: I'm not going to comment on "The Hunger Games" or "The Condemned."  Having said that, Battle Royale is THE REAL THING.  There is nothing cleaned up for PG or for younger audiences.  There is serious violence here.  It is very well done - not overdone fountains of blood, but relatively realistic blood.  The story is basic - unruly kids placed on an island and forced to fight to the death.  The students react in different ways, from rejection and termination, to suicide, to all out slaughter.  It's gory and fun.  There is a plot, but it becomes more evident in the second movie.  The set has 4 discs - two are different versions of the first movie.  One disc is BRII, and the last is extras.  Good stuff, but most is in Japanese.  Actually, the whole thing is in Japanese, but the subtitles are very good.  About BRII - I know a lot of people panned it, but I think it is necessary.  There are a lot of loose ends and unanswered questions at the end of BRI.  BRII attempts to answer them.  I am not always happy with the answers.  Many of them are quite anti-American, but at least there is an attempt to answer questions about how things changed so much that a BR-type spectacle could happen in a civilized country.It's not for everyone.  Some kids may find the hyper-violence upsetting.  There are many references to children being 'at war' with adults.  There is extreme and graphic violence, and references to sexual abuse of a preadolescent female. Adults and the government are viewed as enemies, and (particularly in BRII) the United States is portrayed unfavorably. This is not a film for younger viewers.
summary: Awesome - but not for younger viewers.

reviewText: We read that this was on Quentin Tarantino's top movies list and was being released on Blu-Ray, and of course the comparisons to the Hunger Games series also raised our interest.  It started with a warning that no one under 15 is allowed to watch - and that is a good warning.  I would not recommend letting kids under that age watch because this movie is extraordinarily violent, more so than many American films.The movie takes place somewhere in the not too distant future in Japan.  There is a totalitarian government that uses a ruthless demonstration of power (The Battle Royale Act) to gain control over the people because there is a perceived lack of authority for adults and government.  Mild Spoiler alert but this happens in the opening minutes of the movie:  9th grade students from the Shiroiwa Junior High School in the town of Shiroiwa are on a bus going on a school trip when they are gassed and wake up on an evacuated island, Okishima Island School.  They are immediately placed in a room and surrounded by soliders.  It is explained that they have been selected as part of the BR - the Battle Royale games.  There are 21 boys and 21 girls - a total of 42 students.  They must fight each other to the death.  They are advised that they will be given a bag that contains bread and water, and a weapon - some good, some not so good - and that the games last three days.  There are no real rules other than to kill every other kid and survive.  There can only be one survivor.  They are tracked by a metal device on their necks. They are told that certain areas are off limits at certain times of day.The most troubling aspect of the film is the relationship between the children and how some are too eager to turn on each other with extreme hatred, while others bond and try to form alliances that are troubled by paranoia. The question I believe the film asks is what would you do under such circumstances? Would you kill other innocents to save yourself, or would you try and help others?  Some reviews suggest that to truly understand this movie you must understand Japanese history and the relationship between the government and the people. Not being Japanese I assume there were layers of meaning and messages that I simply missed.  So, as a foreign consumer the real question is whether the movie is still any good or not.This movie was indeed very different and we enjoyed it for what it was (if enjoy is the right word for a movie that shows children killing other children) but it definitely is not for everyone.  This collection includes 4 DVD's: the director's cut, the theatrical release, the sequel (which is just terrible, and way too long), and a bonus DVD of extras.  I would recommend the full collection only if you are a serious fan of this movie and will spend the time to delve through all the extra content.  Otherwise, you would be fine with the just the main feature.  If you enjoy off-beat movies that are not a re-hash of the same movie you have seen a million times, and like your movies a bit "violent," you should at least enjoy watching this cult favorite.

reviewText: First out of the gate, I have to mention the packaging.  Most special edition/box set packaging is beautiful and artistic, but highly impractical - Evil Dead 2, soft and shaped like the Necronomicon, case in point.  The box set may be cool but is generally impractical and takes up too much space.  The Battle Royale set, on the other hand, is essentially a hardcover book with thick cardboard pages, where each disc slides into one of the pages.  The book is elegantly designed and well thought out, and takes up less room on your video shelf than 4 separate Blu-Ray discs.Now on to the movies.  "Battle Royale" is a classic; it's simple, direct and to the point.  At the same time, it works on many levels.  At the most basic level, it's a very basic allegory of the Japanese educational system, and you will get that because the movie comes right out and says so a couple of times.  At another level, it's about the conflict between the powerful and the powerless.  Fundamentally, I think the ultimate message is that when you're thrust into a conflict not of your making, against your will, the best thing to do is simply not participate.  Consider the last 45 minutes or so and the choices the final few contestants make.  It's a more visceral, bloodier "Hunger Games" 10+ years ahead of the "Hunger Games," and it succeeds very well."Battle Royale 2" had to come out bigger in scope than the first one, and it certainly does; I won't spoil it by saying exactly how.  It's not an allegory but rather an awkward polemic about American imperialism.  I'm as anti-imperialist as the next guy, but man does this movie lay it on thick.  It builds directly on the ending of the first movie, and opens with a definite allegory to events of the recent past.  I don't want to describe it too much, because pretty much any detail I give you is a spoiler.  Like "Survivor," this round of BR changes the rules, and the rule changes aren't always for the best.  Another problem with BR2 is that it runs out of steam after the first hour and never really gets its momentum back.Both films fall down a little in terms of cause and effect plotting and continuity.  Asian cinema generally doesn't get too uptight about that stuff; American audiences expect it.  In more than a few places, you stop and think, well, why did X just happen in light of what we were told 10 minutes ago?  Battle Royale moves quickly enough that this doesn't happen too much.  Battle Royale 2, particularly at the end, gives you a lot more time to ponder the plot, and that's a bad thing.The bonus disc has fewer special features than I would have expected, but they're still interesting.  I always like seeing some of what the cast and crew does behind the scenes.This is a great set for fans of Asian cinema, action/horror, or just something different from what you'll see at the multiplex.

reviewText: Ah, "Battle Royale". It was, until "The Hunger Games", probably the quintessential movie about middle school kids butchering one another. I've seen the movie, I've read the novel and read most of the manga, and despite the insanely unrealistic premise, I find a lot in the series that I really like, which is ironic given how much I hated, hated, hated "The Hunger Games". I could, and probably should, do a blog article about why I like the one and not the other, but that's not what this review is about. No, it's about "Battle Royale", now available on blu ray.You probably already know the plot: in an alternate history, Japan passes laws mandating that one middle school class each year (around 42 students), will be taken to an island, given an assortment of weapons, and told they must kill each other until only one is left. I never quite got what this was supposed to accomplish, and I'm 99% sure that were it tried in the real world, you'd have an uprising like you wouldn't believe, but there you go. A few years later, a sequel featuring some of the same cast was also released, but it got less-than-stellar reviews, and even now, I haven't bothered to watch it.I bought "Battle Royale" in DVD form several years ago, and found it utterly fascinating. I no longer have that DVD, but memories of it remain fresh in my mind, so I can easily make a comparison to that DVD release and this blu ray, and the comparison is this: it's so much better that it might as well be a different movie. The blu ray version has a better, less awkward translation and localization, the colors look better and the sound is better. Yes, kids, you can really hear it when one boy gets stabbed in the crotch! Fun times!There's also an entire disc of special features, including "making of" stuff, a press conference, some comments from Quentin Tarantino, who took much inspiration from this movie, and an interesting SFX deconstruction, for those of you who simply MUST know how to make it look like a fourteen-year-old boy's throat just exploded without the mess of getting some C4.You get the director's cut of the first movie, as well as a theatrical cut. You also get "Battle Royale II: Requiem," though as I said, from everything I've heard it isn't worth bothering with. Then you get that extra disc of special features. All in all you get quite a lot of entertainment value for your money."Battle Royale" is easily the most influential film to come out of Japan this century. It's a very worthwhile movie and I'm pleased to see that it finally got the release it deserved here in the USA. Kudos all around to everyone involved!

reviewText: This film (based on the 1999 novel of the same name) was quickly banned by many outlets.  The public outrage was enormous. Now, years later, this has become one of the most sought after films never officially released in the US.I received a copy thanks to Amazon Vine, not five days after my partner bought the novel from a local bookstore (creepy huh!).  Since we read the Hunger Games series, we've been on a kick with these styles of novels/films starting with Lord of the Flies.  And in the great tradition of Golding's novel, these contemporary novels (and films based on) pit a group of teenagers against one another in a gruesome battle.  Where Lord of the Flies broke the ice, more modern works definitely go the extra mile.  None really capture the raw bloodlust, horror, and awe of this novel and film (though the film is tame compared to the novel!).  And that would be the one problem I have.  There is one key scene involving eye gouging that is in the book, but is not in the movie.  It was a pretty shocking and graphically depicted scene in the book, but it was a key moment of the novel, and its exclusion from the movie is a little disappointing.  The endings are also vastly different.  I won't mention anything that would spoil it.  I think the film ending was a little hokey.The film release I received is a 4 disc set on Blu-Ray.  The picture quality is amazing.  So precise you can see the individual blood droplets spraying out of a wound.  The first disc is the film (director's cut), the second is the theatrical release, the third is the sequel: Requiem, and the final disc is one of the best extras collections around.  The special features are wildly entertaining and are very interesting.  They have press interviews with the cast and crew, making of specials, a documentary, TV promos, and more.Now don't get me wrong: the film is bloody, but not in a cheesy, gory, B-movie kind of way.  Instead the violence is key, and the blood is added just as an after effect of the violence it seems.  But the violence is key here.  That is what is shocking.  Take 42 15 year old Junior High kids (as in the book, though they mention High School kids in the film - probably safer that way), and put them in a compound for a military experiment where they receive a horde of weapons and fight until the last kid is standing.  It's Hunger Games with more violence, more victims, and guns.  It's a slap in the face to modern sensibilities and a cry out against the government of the 90s in Japan that allowed rampant corruption and failed to act on a steadily weakening economy while lashing out at the youth of Japan for not doing their part.  The author, Koushun Takami, worked for a news media company before completing the novel (hence his disgust with all of the stories he wrote centered around the aforementioned topics).The main actor is familiar to those who enjoy Japanese film: he was also Kira in Death Note. In this film he is younger and his acting is not quite as even as it is in his later films.  Still, he is believable in a sometimes overly dramatic fashion (like the scene after the lighthouse).  The guy who plays Shogo is amazing though.  I really like what the director did with his character.  My only beef was the slight change to the ending from the novel.  It works for the film, but it almost contradicts the purpose of the film and is confusing when compared to the novel.  But taking a 600 page novel and converting into a 2 hour film?  I am willing to accept these minor changes.  And many of the other changes made in the interest of packing in as much as possible.This continues a string of gritty Japanese films that seem to reflect the mood in the country throughout the 1990s (The lost decade it has been called). The other notable school kid shock film that is available in the US is Suicide Club.  But regardless, Battle Royale fueled a movement, and the film is amazing for the chances taken and the overall success.  It was nominated for 10 Japanese Academy Awards and spawned a manga and a rumored upcoming anime series.  This film is banned in many countries around the globe and was available in very limited quantities before this new release.  My advice is to snatch up the 4 disc Blu-Ray while you can.  And read the novel as well.  It's amazing!It would have been better produced as a series or as an anime I think (more screen time to work with), and it should have been a bit more graphic, like the novel.  I miss the eye gouging from the novel!  But it's still great.  Understandably, they really couldn't get too crazy with it or it would have never been released even in Japan!
summary: Good novel, but the book is far superior!

reviewText: "Battle Royale: The Complete Collection" is a very good box set edition for this title.  The films themselves are very dark, but look absolutely beautiful on Blu-ray.The first film, set in a dystopian future Japan where adults fear unruly children, sees one middle school class of 40+ students sent to a deserted island and each teenager is given only one objective- be the last one standing.  Given various weapons like guns, knives, crossbows, and even poor "weapons" such as a pot lid and binoculars, the students engage in an orgy of blood as they turn on each other in their quest for survival.  Some students, however, reject the blood sport and seek a way around the violence by embracing compassion.  A dark, gory film that treads a dangerous line of glorifying violence, this film is not for everyone.The sequel takes on an interesting premise, and doesn't merely repeat the formula of the first film.  Unfortunately, the direction it takes is not nearly as intense or engaging as the original.  Still, fans of the first film will enjoy the continuation of the story and the copious amounts of blood.Not entirely original, these films borrow heavily from such science-fiction, war, and coming-of-age films as "Lord of the Flies", "The Running Man", "Red Dawn", and "Taps", and of course I doubt it's a coincidence that this set is being released around the same time as the major Hollywood production of "The Hunger Games" is set to open.  Superficially, "Battle Royale" and "The Hunger Games" sound a lot alike.If you enjoy coming of age and dystopian tales, and are not put off by a virtual blood-bath in every other frame, you might enjoy checking out this treat from Japan.

reviewText: Battle Royale: The Complete Collection set is available today, Tuesday, March 20th on both DVD and Blu-ray (Battle Royale is also available as a single disc DVD or Blu-ray as well).This is a review of the Blu-ray set as a whole along with its special features. Be sure to check out my full reviews for both Battle Royale The Director's Cut and Battle Royale II: Requiem.The Complete Collection has some pretty incredible packaging that includes a sleek slip cover and a really nice book that holds all four discs and features several production shots and stills from both movies.Disc 1 is the Director's Cut of Battle Royale. It's offered in Japanese Dolby TrueHD 7.1 and English Dolby TrueHD 5.1. English subtitles are also included with a widescreen presentation and a 1.78:1 aspect ratio. It has a 122-minute runtime. It had been something like six years since I last saw Battle Royale, but I can guarantee it never looked or sounded this good. The classical score sounds phenomenal and every ounce of bloodshed is so crystal clear. This is the way Battle Royale was meant to be seen.Disc 2 is the Theatrical Cut of Battle Royale. It's offered in Japanese Dolby TrueHD 5.1 with English subtitles and a widescreen presentation with a 1.78:1 aspect ratio. It has a 114-minute runtime.Disc 3 is Battle Royale II: Requiem. It's offered in Japanese Dolby True HD 5.1 with English subtitles and a widescreen presentation with a 1.78:1 aspect ratio. This was my first viewing of BR II, so I didn't really have anything to compare it to other than the original film. While the sequel certainly looked and sounded great, it just didn't come anywhere close to living up to its predecessor. What's interesting is that this is the theatrical version of the film and clocks in at around 134 minutes while a director's cut version of the film that's nearly twenty minutes longer does exist and is currently available on DVD.Disc 4 is special features. This is actually a DVD. The Blu-ray version of the collection has three Blu-ray discs (BR Director's Cut, BR Theatrical Cut, BRII) and the DVD of special features for four discs in total. The special features are offered in Japanese Dolby Surround 2.0 with English subtitles and are presented in Full-Frame with a 1.33:1 aspect ratio. That's the main issue with the DVD is the full frame. Here's a full list of the 13 special features:"The Making of Battle Royale""Battle Royale Press Conference""Instructional Video: Birthday Version""Audition and Rehearsal Footage""Special Effects Comparison Featurette""Tokyo International Film Festival 2000""Battle Royale Documentary""Basketball Scene Rehearsals""Behind-the-Scenes Featurette""Filming On-Set""Original Theatrical Trailer""Special Edition TV Spot""TV Spot: Tarantino Version""The Making of" is the longest special feature clocking in at just over fifty minutes, but its weakness is that a lot of the dialogue isn't subtitled. A good portion of what isn't subtitled are scenes from the movie, but there are times when director Kinji Fukasaku is yelling things at the actors or the cast is speaking into the camera and you have no idea what they're saying. It seems like some of it is kind of important, too. "The Making of," "Documentary," and "Behind-the-Scenes" featurettes all share similar footage as well. So while they are interesting, they do get a little redundant. The "Special Effects" featurette may be the highlight of the special features as it compares what was originally shot in the film to each effect that was added and is set to classical music, which is a nice touch. Altogether, the special features add up to two hours six minutes and eighteen seconds.While Battle Royale II is certainly lacking, it's mostly just an extra to an already excellent release. There really isn't much else you could possibly desire regarding Battle Royale except for the director's cut of Battle Royale II.Battle Royale was never theatrically released in the states, so this is its first official release stateside. If you're going to bring a great foreign film here, you might as well give it the best treatment imaginable with fantastic picture and sound. That's exactly what Anchor Bay has done here. You've never had a better reason to either revisit one of the greatest foreign films ever or finally have the chance to experience it for the first time. reviewText: Imagine this: a country is run by a totalitarian government, which occasionally selects groups of teenagers to methodically kill each other, until only one remains."The Hunger Games"? No, actually it's "Battle Royale," a bloody and harrowing movie that came out several years earlier, depicting an alternate Japan where the youth are forced to kill each other. The first film one of those movies that is strangely fascinating and filled with social commentary, but the sequel falls short with its clunky message and suspenseless violence."Battle Royale": A class of high-schoolers are being transported on a bus, when they are gassed to unconsciousness. When they awake, they have electronic collars around their necks. A former teacher named Kitano explains that they have been chosen for the B.R. ("Battle Royale") Act, wherein teenagers are forced to fight each other to the death until only one is left standing.If you don't play, try to escape, refuse to kill or stray into a "death zone," the collars explode. Each teenager is given food, water and a random item, and are set loose on a remote island. As the teens slowly weed each other out, Shuya Nanahara and his girlfriend Noriko try to find a way out that doesn't involve death. But if they refuse to kill, then they must escape the fascist nightmare... which no one has done before."Battle Royale II: Requiem" takes place a few years later -- another group of teenagers are gassed, and wake with the explosive electronic collars. But their Battle Royale is a little different: they're put in pairs and given 72 hours to storm a remote island stronghold and kill Shuya Nanahara (who has since become a terrorist). If one partner dies or runs away, the other one explodes.Sent to attack Shuya and his little band of rebels, the teens are slowly weeded out by gunfire, explosions and their own growing panic. But when set free, they must ask themselves if Shuya is someone they really want to fight against - or someone they want to fight alongside. And they have to ask it fast, because the government is about to storm the island"Battle Royale" is a classic example of a brilliant movie.... and its inferior sequel. Kinji Fukasaku's "Battle Royale" is a masterpiece of shocking violence and social commentary -- it's a bloody, suspenseful look at how humans react under threat of death, and how far people would go to survive. Even more striking is the look at brutal governments who just LOVE punishing innocent people.And the acting is simply sublime. Takeshi Kitano is bonechilling as the former teacher who now sentences his students to death, and Tatsuya Fujiwara and Aki Maeda give stellar performances as ordinary kids who are forced to fight for their freedom.Sadly, the sequel (which was directed by the original director's son, Kenta Fukasaku) doesn't manage the same level of brilliance. It tries to shock us even more by having more people die more violently, but there are only a few scenes of suspense over who will die. So there's just lots of people we don't know being gunned down in a splatter of blood and explosions. Tatsuya Fujiwara is the sole character who is really striking, playing a hardened, haunted man with a crusade.Also, the sequel starkly contradicts the original movie's message, a timeless tale that could be set in any country across the world. Here, the hostility towards Shuya's terrorists is all blamed on the United States (yes, it's not the JAPANESE government's fault, but the US... because we fight terrorists, and all terrorists are secretly good guys), and we get a bizarre hackneyed scene all about how the people of the Middle East are all shining saints. It's doesn't fit the Battle Royale story."Battle Royale/Battle Royale II" contains one brilliant movie and its mediocre sequel, which is notable mainly because of Tatsuya Fujiwara's brilliant performance. So watch the first, skip the second.

reviewText: By itself, the first film in the series would be worth 5 stars. At this point in time, BR has become a sort of institution and its place amongst the pantheon of cult classics has been carved in stone. If you've not seen the film you've certainly missed out. The film is part of a genre that really could never exist in the US. It's a genre that the Japanese have perfected and done to great success. It could best be described as the Ultraviolent Teen genre. It generally involves Jr. or Sr. High School age kids that do all manner of violent acts.BR takes place in an authoritarian Japanese future where the youth have become so disrespectful and sociopathic that the government has passed the Battle Royale act. Each year, one class is randomly chosen to be placed on an island where classmates are forced to kill one another until there is only one left. The idea is that this ominous, existential threat will create some order amongst the younger generations. The film centers on the outing of one particular class and there experience in the Hunger Ga. . . I mean Battle Royale.There are those that will immediately write the film off due to its story. But they would be missing something very special. What makes BR so great isn't that it is just an all-out bloodbath for two hours. The film is loaded with humanity. And what's even more special is that, despite being stuck in this game, the audience is still shown that these are kids dealing with problems that kids have. Some of the violence is motivated by those who feel left out or abandoned. Some have secret crushes while others still want nothing more than to belong. And even though these kids know that only one can survive, many of them still choose friendship over murder. The film requires several viewings to fully absorb all the different levels of story that are being told. It truly is a film that gets better and better with each viewing. And Japanese legend Takeshi Kitano is absolutely brilliant as the teacher who oversees his former class in the games. There are very few characters that could be called 2-dimensional. Despite there be so many students, each has their own backstory and their own motivations. Each will play the game differently based on their personalities and relationships and status amongst the class.On to the package itself. The Blu Ray looks great. I wouldn't say it's a reference copy. But it is incredibly clean and a noticeable improvement from the DVD version. The extras are great. Having both the theatrical and director's version of the film is a bonus, although I suggest the director's cut as the better film. The sequel is fine, but pales in comparison to the first film. The boxing is well done and will be a nice addition to any movie shelf.The film is a drama, a character piece with little pieces of violence scattered throughout. I'd not call it an action movie, it's far deeper. The action is often times not played up at all. Some students are killed very quickly and with little ceremony, giving a great feel for the fleeting nature of life. The film is loaded with social and moral observations, but never preaches. At the bottom of it all is just the idea of simple human kindness and friendship. It may seem like a silly idea considering the subject matter. But, in fact, the message is a powerful one that becomes even stronger when placed in the context of such abhorrent acts but such innocent individuals.Suzanne Collins claims she had never heard of BR before writing Hunger Games. I can't tell you if it's true or not. But I will say that the release of HG has certainly had a wonderful impact on bringing BR back into the spotlight. Don't miss out on one of the greatest and most original stories in contemporary cinema, the film that even Tarantino has repeatedly called his favorite film of all time. It is certainly worthy of the praise. The Blu Ray package is worth every penny (and several more) for those that already own the previous versions. Buy it. Watch it. Love it. Watch it again!

reviewText: Battle Royale: The story of a dystopian society in which a single high school class is chosen at random and relocated to a deserted island in which the kids must fight to the death. If the description itself intrigues you, then you won't be disappointed.The entire history behind Battle Royale itself is a rather intriguing one that can't be covered in this one review, though makes for a fun reading if you're curious and want to do a google search. Just know that North America has had the bad luck of school shootings and terrorist attacks deter any interest in releasing these two Japanese films until now. Though, while most of the heat the series takes is from the United States, it's interesting to note that the back of the packaging seems to suggest that this particular release is aimed towards a Canadian market, what with their "Made in Canada" sticker and Canadian movie rating, in comparison to the simple "Not Rated" blurb included for us in the states. Just an interesting observation.As mentioned, the movies themselves are top notch, covering everything you'd expect in terms of violence as well as themes. The first movie is a very loose adaptation of the book, so I suggest picking that up for a more complete understanding, though the movie does a good job of standing well on its own. The second movie, in general, is also enjoyable enough, though without a second novel to base it off of, some consider this one significantly weaker than its predecessor. Regardless, there are enough twists in the sequel that separate itself from the first one and is a decent follow-up, though somewhat preachy.My only gripes come from analyzing the small details--mostly in terms of the packaging. The set itself is presented in a book-style format, where each disc is inside the "sleeve" of a page. This makes removing and inserting each disc something of a chore in comparison to standard packaging. If you're afraid of scratching any discs, I'd recommend just keeping removing them and keeping them in a CD carrier, or something else more convenient. Each page of the booklet provides a nice spread, either taking screen captures from the movies or aspects from them, like the map, or student roster. What would have been helpful, though, is translating some of the text. While I thoroughly enjoyed the first movie, there are a good number of names tossed around, so having the student roster list with their pictures attached be translated would have been a big help. Additional minute details, like some screen captures being repeated between pages and the background picture for the grid of Area 6 not lining up with the grid itself when comparing with Areas 1-5 (the back of the page that holds disc 1, for reference) make for an overall sloppy design. The artwork for the back of the package is also notably spoiler-ey for the first film, crossing out all but the major characters as dead.The choice of disc artwork also leaves me stumped. While there is clarification in the booklet itself as to which disc holds what movie, there's absolutely no indication of this on the discs themselves. A simple "director's cut" or "theatrical cut" would have been fine. Instead, each disc is marked by number with the text "Battle Royale" and "Survival Program." Not the most specific of text, especially when every disc has it. At the least, I would have expected use of the "BRII" logo for the disc containing the second disc, but no dice.I should also mention that while the set has the Director's Cut and Theatrical Cut of the first movie (opinion seems rather split on which is better; I personally go with the Director's Cut if only for more footage), the Director's Cut for the second movie (apparently titled "Battle Royale: Revenge") is nowhere to be seen in this release. Normally, I wouldn't be too peeved about this, but to have two versions of one movie, and only one version of its sequel makes the titles of "The Complete Collection" rather misleading.Still, I'm glad a North American release has made obtaining this movie significantly easier for fans as well as newcomers to the series that want to see a dystopian movie done the right way.
summary: No 2nd Movie Director's Cut, but good release overall

reviewText: I feel like the odd one out reviewing this movie, I had never heard of it or seen any of it before.  The brief descriptions compared it loosely to Hunger Games, and as that was all the rage, I thought I would give it a try.  After viewing the directors cut of Battle Royale, I don't see too many similarities to Hunger Games at all, just the general idea of kids killing kids. I found this movie entertaining in the sense it was a whole new genre to me and it didn't seem predictable at all.  The acting by the child killers was a bit overly dramatic at times, and it seemed like none of them was really afraid of death, but was rather philosophical about it.  It wasn't at all like generic American made horror films where someone is being chased and they are quivering, indecisive and there is pure terror in their eyes.  In Battle Royale, killers and victims can have a discussion, make numerous facial expressions and fight with exaggerated movements.  Not complaining at all though, I prefer it that way, to me it made the movie seem less realistic so that I didn't feel like the character was suffering in their death.  Weird to explain I guess, but I think if you could make killing people feel less serious in a movie, they did it.  It is still a powerful movie.  I watched it in Japanese, with English subtitles and had no problems with it all.The character of the head teacher/sadist guy is very well done.  He is almost robotic in his emotions, and you get a glimpse into his psyche at the end of the movie.  The Army officers in the background seemed goofy at times, and that is another instance in how the movie is made to feel less serious.  Overall, I liked the movie, as much as you can like watching people kill each other I suppose.  I can well imagine the furor it must have caused when it was release 12 years ago in Japan. reviewText: With the emergence of "The Hunger Games" phenomenon of the last few years, the inevitable comparisons between that franchise and the cult novel "Battle Royale" by Koushun Takami have been plentiful. Sure, the two do share strong thematic and narrative similarities, but each has a distinctly unique vibe and explores the back story behind the violence in a different way. The film adaptation of "Battle Royale" by director Kenji Fukasaku garnered almost instant international notoriety in 2000 for its disturbingly bleak portrait of kids set upon one another in a violent death match. Despite being banned and reviled by many, the story's visceral and emotional punch was hard to deny. It was nominated for numerous Japanese Academy Awards including Best Film, Best Actor, Best Director and Best Screenplay and won that country's "Popularity Award." The rumor that Hollywood was flirting with an American remake has been circulating for years, but some seem to think that the film adaptation of "The Hunger Games" might have hurt the likelihood of this occurrence. In any event, I never had high hopes that an American interpretation could rival the original."Battle Royale" is being released in two incarnations, a film only DVD/ Blu-ray or "The Complete Collection" DVD/Blu-ray.Film Only: This includes the Director's Cut of the film. First, the story is about a future Japan whose economy is in collapse and whose crime rate is spiraling out-of-control. In an effort to temper this uptick in violence by the juvenile population, the government has sanctioned an annual contest. In the movie, forty-two middle school aged students are dropped off and left to battle one another for survival. They are armed and coerced into fighting, for there can be only one winner left alive. As often as I've seen this movie, it never fails to shock and disturb me as it is exceptionally intense and powerful. Some complain that it isn't as "good" as the source novel (which is a pretty common argument with most translations from the page to the screen), but I think this is a daring and audacious film that succeeds fully on its own merits. I'm not, however, a huge fan of the Director's Cut. I don't think the extra footage adds appreciable value to the movie and I don't love the extended finale. This version has no special features.Complete Collection (4 discs): The four discs are (1) Director's Cut of the film (see above), (2) Theatrical Cut, (3) 2003's "Battle Royale II" and (4) Bonus Content Disc. While I would certainly consider the original "Battle Royale" as a classic, its sequel is less so. It carries the same concept over to a new class with some variations on the original theme, but the major difference is that an underground plot by an unexpected terrorist cell plays a large part in this year's action. It's solid enough, I like it. It just lacks the emotional kick of the first film.Bonus Disc Content included in Complete Collection only. reviewText: I had heard of the movie BATTLE ROYALE years ago and actually had a chance to see a portion of the sequel. My son has always told me it was an amazing film but until this release I'd never had the chance or time to watch it (even though I borrowed his copy months ago). Fans of the film were hard pressed to find a copy and for the most part the only way to do so was via bootleg copies or those sold at fan conventions over the past few years. But that has all changed with the release of this box set put together by Anchor Bay.Included are the directors cut of the original film as well as the theatrical cut, the sequel and a collection of extras that include The Making of Battle Royale, TV Spot: Tarantino Version, Basketball Scene Rehearsals, Tokyo International Film Festival 2000, Special Edition TV Spot, Original Theatrical Trailer, Battle Royale Documentary, Special Effects Comparison Featurette, Filming On-Set, Behind-The-Scenes Featurette, Audition & Rehearsal Footage, Instructional Video: Birthday Version, and Battle Royale Press Conference. As you can see they've covered nearly all the bases with this one. The transfer is beautifully done and the colors and film footage nearly leap off the screen, which could be a bad thing considering the amount of blood shed during the film. With two films to discuss, I'll break them down.BATTLE ROYALEThe story takes place in the near future. Unemployment is at an all time high and people are beginning to give up hope, especially the young generation. Rather than sit back and accept things as they are, the youngsters tend to express their rage through violence and disrespect. In response the adults pass a law and form Battle Royale, a competition that is literally life or death.The worst 9th grade class is taken on a field trip and gassed but when they wake they don't find themselves home. Instead they are find themselves in a large room surrounded by soldiers. When their teacher arrives he explains they are now part of BR and how it works. Each student has a collar. Should they try to take it off or escape, the collar explodes. The students will each be issued a backpack that will contain food, water and a weapon. Once they get their pack, they are to leave. They are on a deserted island now and there is one thing they need to accomplish: survive to be the last person alive at the end of 3 days. Yes, each student is to kill the rest to win. Should there be more than one survivor, those remaining will all die. To make it more of a challenge they've also been given a map that shows a grid and every 6 hours the grid changes with hot zones that will explode their collars.The biggest turmoil for these kids is of course being able to kill someone to continue living. But there's more to the story than that. Keep in mind these are junior high students, kids who are in the midst of making friends, making enemies, being picked on or being popular. All of those things that teens go through come into play with the interaction between them all. Alliances can be made but for how long knowing that if you don't kill the rest you all end up dead? To make matters worse, two wild cards are brought in, two students not from this class who seem to be trouble makers of the worst sort.The film moves at a furious pace with plenty of action and fairly gory effects. As each student is killed or commits suicide, the count changes with each now dead classmate having their names added to the daily announcements. Some react as you would think a normal person would, others seem to care less. This is survival of the fittest taken to extremes.Two students have joined forces, a couple that never had the chance to actually become a couple. Shuya and Noriko find themselves caring for one another more than they though possible. Both want to make it and aren't sure how they can do so with both of them alive. When a chance presents itself for that to happen, they jump at it.The movie is brutal and shocking but at the same time tells a great story. It makes you consider the thought; could I actually kill my best friend in order to continue living? At the heart of the film that's what makes it work so well, confronting the concept in your own mind and applying it to yourself. If anyone thinks they can come up with the truth as an answer you're kidding yourself. Who knows what one would do when put in that situation? The ending of the film works well but I won't spoil it here.BATTLE ROYALE II: REQUIEMThe sequel is well done but doesn't quite live up to the first. SPOILER ALERT: If you don't want to know how the first film ends then watch it before reading below.It begins 3 years after the last film. Shuya and Noriko survived the first film and escaped the island. With a tremendous grudge against the adults who made them play the game, they are now wanted fugitives. Rather than except their predicament, they become terrorists out to bring down the adults of the world. In response to their attacks and propaganda, the government passes another law creating Battle Royale II.The same starting principle holds true with a group of 9th graders brought to a military base after being sleep gassed. When they wake they find themselves in a cage with their new teacher telling them the rules. Instead of hunting one another they will be dropped on an island with their backpacks in order to put an end to Shuya's declaration of war on all adults. Their job is to kill Shuya and his followers. Should they decline to do so they will immediately be killed via collar. Added to this is the problem that they are to work in pairs. Should one die, the other finds themselves victim of the collar.Placed in boats and heading for the island they find themselves under attack before they hit the shore. Between being shot en route and when they land, nearly a third of the 42 kids are gone before they receive ammunition and have the chance to find cover. Once more the mind set of the teen is played and they more often resort to the tantrums or emotional upheavals teens do rather than think things through. Once they begin to do so they become a more effective unit.The biggest difference between this film and the original is the involvement of politics. Condemnation of governments and those in charge runs rampant here. The idea of teens taking over the world harkens back to the sixties and the concept of trust no one over 30. Yes, the adults have messed things up pretty bad, but the chances of these kids saving the world don't seem much better.Eventually the combatants realize what is going on and unite forces. Shuya and his group disable the collars and keep the new teens armed and ready. This means that the military must now go in to take them all out. Who will survive and who will die isn't seen until the film's end.So there you have it, the stories behind the movie and sequel. Are they worth watching? By all means. And if this is the sort of movie you can enjoy in one way or another, it's also one that you should add to your collection. As I said, the transfer to DVD is beautiful to see. The acting is amazing even when the film is in Japanese (the first is dubbed, the second subtitled). For all the controversy that surrounded this film, it is one you should seek out.

reviewText: If you think that THE HUNGER GAMES is something and haven't yet seen Kinji Fukasaku's BATTLE ROYALE films, you need this box set. You get a lot for your money here: both versions of BATTLE ROYALE, the sequel, BATTLE ROYALE II: REQUIEM and a Special Features disc that is actually pretty interesting compared to others. Prior to getting this set, I had only seen the slightly longer Special Edition of BATTLE ROYALE, and this version remains the one that most fans will want to see. It's the only film in the set with 7.1 sound. To me, there isn't a significant difference between the Special Edition and the original Theatrical Cut, but it's nice to have them both. Either way, you have here a film that you'll either love or hate. It's extremely violent and disturbing, but also outrageously satirical in its depiction of teenagers drafted by the government to battle each other until only one is left alive. Intense performances by the teen actors, some of whom were in their twenties, will hold your interest. And I can't forget "Beat" Takeshi Kitano's role as the teacher/C.O. who whips his class into a homicidal frenzy; it's one of his best outings. As for the sequel, it will surprise no one that it's not quite as good. There's less character development and less story in BR II, but it's still not bad and certainly worth a look. A saving grace is the deliciously hammy Riki Takeuchi (TOKYO MAFIA) in a similar role to Kitano's; Riki really chews the scenery here in quite an amusing fashion. Also watch for a cameo by Shinichi "Sonny" Chiba. All three movie discs boast outstanding picture and sound quality.The director, Kinji Fukasaku, had a fascinating career. He's probably best known in Japan for his Yakuza films, especially BATTLES WITHOUT HONOR AND HUMANITY, aka The Yakuza Papers. Fukasaku also directed the cult favorite THE GREEN SLIME, and stepped in when Akira Kurosawa was fired during the making of TORA! TORA! TORA!. Fukasaku's many fans should love this set's Special Features disc, as it shows him up close and personal during the making of the first BATTLE ROYALE. The affable Fukasaku, who, at this point, only had about two years to live, expends more energy than the younger cast and crew who surround him. His accounts of the World War II horrors he experienced are haunting. There is over two hours' worth of material on the Special Features disc, and it's all worth your time.It should be noted that, while the movie discs are Blu-rays, the Special Features disc is in DVD format. It doesn't matter that much to me, as both are watchable in Blu-ray players, though I can envision some buyers being irritated at this.What is highly irritating to me about this set is the packaging. Yes, its imitation book format looks kool, but the discs are in cardboard sleeves and are very difficult to remove. Two of them had to be pulled pretty hard to get them to come out- this bothers me, because I try never to touch a disc's playing surface. It was similarly difficult to replace the discs, and the sleeves would not accommodate paper envelopes. So, I may end up keeping the discs in conventional boxes. Note to video manufacturers: please avoid cardboard sleeves! Many of us prefer to keep our discs in top condition, which is scarcely possible with this sort of packaging.Packaging aside, though, Anchor Bay has a winner here. All fans of Japanese cinema and outrageous cinema in general should own this set.

reviewText: A fun bit of trivia for anyone keeping track: Battle Royale was released in 1999 in Japan, yet took 13 years to make it to the North American market. At Otakon in I believe 2003, John Sirabella offered to license the BR movie but was told "never" because Toei was told, by I believe Miramax, that there was no way this would ever be released in the US and any company trying to do so would be sued out of existence. This is all hearsay of course, but John indicated his company (Tokyo Shock) even offered to take over any legal troubles if any should arise. They were denied.Here we are, on the cusp of Hunger Games being released in theaters, and magically it's been licensed! I won't go into the parallels of BR and Hunger Games and leave you to decide if Hunger Games is a rip off or whether it just followed a similar developmental path as BR and came to similar conclusions.The first film is well executed. You have a class of 42 students who are forced to fight one another until only a single student is left. That final survivor is deemed the winner of the games and supposedly sent home. The reason for the BR program isn't really too well touched upon and the book explains it in, obviously, more detail. This story takes place in an alternate universe where Japan is part of a larger Asian country/fellowship and this program is designed to keep the population in control.The second film takes the premise of the first, showing what happens after the games and then, while the winners of the BR program are invited to join a resistance force of sorts, the BR program turns from killing one another into killing the rebels. The premise is weaker and the film suffers for it. It also doesn't help the original's director died, leaving it unfinished. Who knows what we would have gotten had he been able to finish?Also included is a "director's cut" of the first film. Added are scenes that develop characters a bit more and also adds some kind of stupid CG blood splatters.Video:BR's video is very good for what it is. Colors are sometimes muted and detail can be lost in shadows, but I believe this is a problem with the original source material.BR2 looks fantastic. Clear, detailed and bright. Well done.Audio:Really? The audio on this is FANTASTIC. I only watched using the Japanese language options (7.1 on BR DC and BR 2, 5.1 only on the original theatrical version). Lots of directionality and every channel gets a workout. I was surprised, as I expected a lot less and got a lot more.Packaging:This is a mixed bag. They tried their hardest to make this seem like a book, though overall I question the long term practicality of the design. Well done, certainly, but a bit of a pain to get into.Extras:The extras are extensive and well researched. It is, however, ONLY in SD as they are all on the included DVD. If you watch the films and enjoy them, digging into the interviews and so on is highly recommended.Final verdict:If you want to see what all the fuss was about, check this out. If you want to see an example of fine Japanese cinema and want to read deeper into it, check this out. If you want to be entertained and don't mind some over the top violence, check this out.If you aren't a fan of Japanese cinema, don't care about the controversy and hate violence, these fillms are definitely NOT for you.Well executed release that any fan of Japanese cinema is likely to enjoy. Top quality audio is unexpected but highly appreciated.

Very few of them add interesting information about how the filming, special effects, or casting was done though all of these are touched upon in some brief fashion. reviewText: Since the Hunger Games has become popular many have pointed out that the premise was done long ago, with Battle Royale.  Thus a resurgence of interest in the film has been prompted by the Hunger Games movies imminent release.  There are plenty of discussions on the internet about the similarities and differences, so if you are interested you can check those out.If you are wondering this is appropriate for your young teen fan of the Hunger Games the short answer is no.  The director must have bought fake blood by the liter, most of the deaths use at least this much blood.  The sheer volume of deaths makes the movie akin to a slasher flick at points but also in some ways very unrealistic. That said, the level of blood and violence is very high, but the gore is minimal.  I have seen episodes of CSI that were more disgusting.  The Japanese gave it a rating that banned those under 15, I think this is a pretty good gauge for the movie's rating.  A mature 16 year old could handle the film.The original film has two primary weaknesses.  The first is the rational for why this Battle Royale is taking place, this is sort of glossed over in the beginning and I thought it might be resolved at the end, but it was not.  The other weakness is the number of stories played out.  The film is always switching back and forth, sometimes giving you whiplash in trying to keep track of what is happening.  The flashbacks and dream sequences do help to explain some of the motivations, but slightly fewer stories, told more deeply might have added more emotional depth to the movie.  I would have like to see the teacher character developed more fully.  But perhaps that is not the point, I by no means call myself a director.The teenagers react in very different ways to being put into this position.  I thought those differences were quite enlightening and thought provoking.  Most watching the film would find at least one to identify with, and the similarities between American teens and Japanese teens are greater than the differences.  When you start to think about how high school dramas might play out if guns, knives and axes were involved you begin to see how the movie is an extrapolation of how bad things can get.  I find it interesting that adults were concerned that the movie would give more students the idea to become school shooters, if anything I think it points out how senseless this violence is, and how it does not solve problems.The sequel (now the 9th graders are fighting the survivors of the first movie)  does not do the first movie justice, it is boring, and the characters behave in manner completely contrary to their beliefs.  The premise was original in the first movie, the second does not match the thought provoking ideas of the first.  The original rates 5 stars, the sequel only 1.  The bonus disc also misses translating some of the dialog so I am rating this set as 4 stars overall.Definitely an interesting movie for adults and older teens, not for the younger set.
summary: NOT for young teens.  Original BR a 5 star move, sequel horrible.

reviewText: Banned in U.S. shores, the original "Battle Royale" (2000) became a much talked-about phenomenon and a copy of the film became sort of a forbidden fruit among cinema fans. It was understandable that America wanted to keep the film away since the very premise of kids killing kids would be highly controversial. It was until later (after 5-6 years) that the theatrical cut of the film was released but then there was an already hot "director's cut' circulating in Asia and Europe. The second film "Battle Royale: Requiem" (2003) attained some success, but it just could not match up with the emotions, horror and dark premise of the first film. Anchor Bay Entertainment has finally released blurays of the two films and boy, do they look pristine in their uncut, unedited form.Battle Royale: Directed by Kinji FukasakuIn a not-so different alternate future, Japan has experienced economic collapse with a massive unemployment rate. With no clear future, students begin to disrespect the education system, with an increase in riots and violence, student drop outs are also occurring at an alarming rate. To control the situation, the government enacts the "Battle Royale Act" that consists of the selection by secret lottery for one of the poorest performing class in the country and sending the students off to an island where they must fight each other to the death until only one is left standing. The students have 72 hours to complete the game or everyone dies from the explosive devices on their necks. They are supplied with random weapons, given special instructions to avoid danger zones and if they make trouble, the army will find them and kill them. Former friends are forced to kill or be killed; the students experience mistrust, fear, confusion and hatred, as chaos run unchecked..."Battle Royale" serves as a cautionary tale for the teen generation. It does start off simply enough, with themes of morality and immorality are presented in the film's first act. There is a small hole but the film's plot holds strong as Fukasaki's adaptation of the novel generates suspense and gritty thrills as there are no dull moments in the film. It also lets its characters speak for themselves, characterization is partly done through the use of flashbacks. Kitano (played by Takashi Kitano) is the former teacher who has his own issues, the students all have different backgrounds, and they all have different reactions to their situation as well differing motivations. I liked the characters especially those of Mitsuko (played by Ayana Noguchi, her character shines in the Special version) and Noriko (Aki Maeda), they appear to be similar sides of the same coin although very different. Shuya Nanahara (Tatsuya Fujiwara, Death Note) is the one person who tries keep his moral beliefs, I may even go as far as his only motivation would be Noriko. Kawada (Taro Yamamoto) is the one student who was mostly an enigma throughout the film, his motivations remained unclear until the final act. The first film also comes alive with a lot of social and political commentaries that made it a cult classic.Highly Recommended! [4  Out of 5 Stars]Battle Royale Requiem: Directed by Kinji and Kenta FukasakuInstead of the original's `reality show' backdrop, this film goes into a much larger environment as  this time the story focuses on one of the survivors of the events of the first movie, Shuya Nanahara (Tatsuya Fujiwara). He has now founded a group made up of former Battle Royale combatants in opposition to this new Japan by performing terrorist attacks all over the country. In response, the Japanese government had created a new game called "Battle Royale 2", which has been indoctrinated by a mysterious enigma (played by Riki Takeuchi). This new game would take new contestants (complete with explosive collars) to an island where Shuya's group "Wild Seven" is believed to have been holed up. The iniative: kill Shuya Nanahara before the expiration of the 3-day deadline.The second film is no less disturbing and dark as the original but there were some issues in the manner it was paced and executed. The second film serves up different surprises and twists, and one question would come to mind; will the new combatants join Shuya's group or will they fulfill their mandate? The same themes that made the film rich with gritty appeal and the kills are as kept in the same gruesome fashion in "Requiem". But despite the film's tempo, Riki Takeuchi just cannot match Takeshi Kitano's performance, and his character lacks solid development. Also, while the film questions Shuya's character whether he is a visionary or a perpetrator, the film struggled to deliver on the emotional drama that made the first film so powerful. It is technically impressive, and "Requiem" does have its moments of raw edginess and grisly atmosphere as it presents a very visceral feel and has a climactic final encounter; however, much of the film is spent with the characters talking that succumbed to uninspired personal issues that came dangerously close to overwrought acting and socio-political rhetoric. It does present some thought-provoking questions as the viewer is set to ponder just who is the hero and who is the damned. Despite its issues, "Requiem" is solid enough as a sequel.Recommended! [3  Out of 5 Stars]Bluray presentation: The set comes in a beautiful case that resembles a notebook that contains 4 discs. It has movie stills and even maps that were seen in the movie. I have to say it was one of the more stylish designs in a bluray case. This includes both the director's cut and theatrical cut of the first film. The image quality of the two movies are real good, and considering the films age, it scores a good 4/5. There are some soft spots, but Anchor Bay did a fabulous job. The true HD audio lost-less sound is just as impressive. This is a great presentation of the film.Extras: Making of featurette, premieres, trailers (even includes a Tarantino version of the trailer), special effects and an instructional video that celebrates the director's birthday. The documentary is a must see for purists. This is the ultimate collection for fans of the films.Blu-Ray Essential [4  Out of 5 Stars]
summary: Anchor Bay Brings Awesomeness to The Japanese Cult Classic into Blu-Ray HD!!

reviewText: So.  At long last, the controversial film "Battle Royale" gets an official US release.I suppose we haveThe Hunger Gamesto thank for that, bringing new interest to this film, as well the distance from the 2003 death of director Fukasaku Kinji.  Fukasaku, a pacifist and anti-violence activist, is best known in Japan for his seriesBattles Without Honor & Humanity. He opposed an American release of "Battle Royale" fearing that Americans would not see the deeper message and only be excited by the violence, which was the opposite intention of his film.Based off of the 1999novel of the same nameby Takami Koshun, Fukasaku also added his personal experience during WWII to "Battle Royale."  As a child working in a munitions factory, when the Americans dropped bombs on the factory Fukasaku and the rest of the children would fling themselves into a dogpile. Afterwards the protected ones on the bottom would dig themselves out from the burned corpses on top.  This experience taught Fukasaku something about the will to survive even at the cost of the deaths of friends, and lead to his hatred and distrust of government and bureaucracy that would willingly send children to their deaths in such a manner."Battle Royale" is often compared to Lord of the Flies, but that is a bit of a misnomer. "Lord of the Flies" was about reverting to primitivism, whereas "Battle Royale" is a futuristic cautionary tale in the tune of1984andBrave New World. The caution at work here is the threat of absolute bureaucracy, and the dangers of the loss of the value of life and respect in a rules-dominated society. This is a threat quite apparent in modern Japan.The actors in "Battle Royale" all deliver excellent performances, including the amazing talent "Beat" Kitano Takeshi playing the appropriately named "Kitano." Because the film was not directed by Kitano, it lacks his beautiful visual style. It does, however, feature one of his riveting paintings. There is a good range of responses from the various actors playing the students, from outright suicide, to panic, to a drive to win to a drive to help. Unfortunately, the character of Kazuo Kiriyama (the machine gun boy) is woefully underdeveloped, and instead of the fierce, cold genius of the book he is a somewhat characterless villain.While a violent film, I wouldn't characterize "Battle Royale" as an action film, or a horror film. Anyone looking for a Hong Kong-style action film should realize that Japan and China are quite different countries with different approach to movies.. "Battle Royale" retains the quietude and patient pacing that is the hallmark of Japanese cinema, and which leaves some viewers bored, who are used to a quicker pacing. The bloodshed, while in great quantity, is also more cartoony in nature, which is also more typical of Japanese films, which does not favor a naturalistic approach.Ii is important to remember that "Battle Royal" was not made for US audiences.  There is an expectation of familiarity with Japanese history, as well as modern societal issues.  Familiarity gives some necessary perspective to this controversial movie, and helps frame it as more than exploitation. It is a political statement, with a subtle message underlying the overt violence. Along with this, knowledge of Japanese culture deepens the understandings of certain scenes, such as when Kitano performs the prescribed exercises, and the training video shown at the beginning. Without understanding, these scenes might come off as merely quaint or odd.This collection also features the sequel, "Battle Royale II."  This was made after Fukasaku Kinji's death, and was directed by his son Fukasaku Kenta.  The sequel is vastly inferior, and not even really worth watching.  It is nice to have for completeness sake, I suppose, but that is the best that can be said about it.
